children.definition: fish, BGU 1095.17 (i A. D.), cf. PRyl. 229.21 (i A. D.), Ev.Jo. 6.9, al., OGI 484.12 ( Pergam., ii A. D.).
fish-shop, τὰς ἐν τῷ ὀ. μαρμαρίνας τραπέζας CIG 2930 ( Tralles).

data.quote: τὰς ἐν τῷ ὀ. μαρμαρίνας τραπέζας

children.definition: fishmonger, Jahresh. 26 Beibl. 51 ( Ephes., i A. D.), OGI 484.21 ( Pergam., ii A. D.).
one who ploughs late, Hes. Op. 490.
art of cookery, cookery-book, Pl.Com. 173.4, Alex. 135.9; things cooked, like Fr. cuisine, ἀστυκὴ ὀ. Longus 4.16.
cook, Hyp. Fr. 259; ὀψαρτυταὶ καὶ μυροποιοί Phld. Mus. p.86 K.; used derisively of a gourmand, Timae. 70.

of or for a cook or cookery: ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη) the art of cookery, Timocl. 37, S.E. M. 6.33, Phlp. in APo. 74.16; ὀ. καὶ μυρεψική Phld. Mus. p.45 K.: -κόν, τό (with or without βιβλίον), cookery-book, Ath. 3.105c, 9.387c, 12.516c; ὀ. λέξεις, γλῶσσαι, Id. 1.5b, 9.387d.
dress or season food, Timae. 71 (metaph.), Ath. 1.18a.

after a long time, at length, late, ἔκ τε καὶ ὀ. τελεῖ, opp. αὐτίκα, Il. 4.161; ὀ. κακῶς ἔλθοι Od. 9.534, etc.; ὀ. διδάσκεσθαι, μανθάνειν, to be late in learning, learn too late, A. Ag. 1425, S. OC 1264; ὀψέ γε φρονεῖς εὖ E. Or. 99; also ὀ. δή Il. 7.399, etc.; ὀ. γοῦν A. l.c.; ὀ. περ Pi. N. 3.80.

children.label: b
children.definition: ὀ. ἀφʼ οὗ . . it is not long since . . , Th. 1.14.

late in the day, at even, Il. 21.232, Od. 5.272, Th. 4.106, etc.; ὀφλεῖν . . ὀ. ὁδοῦ incur a penalty for being out late at night, Pl. Cra. 433a (dub.); late in the season, Hes. Op. 485; ὀ. ἦν, ὀ. ἐγίγνετο, it was, it was getting, late, X. An. 2.2.16, 3.4.36; ἡ μάχη ἐτελεύτα ἐς (v.l. ἕως) ὀ. did not end till late, Th. 3.108; so ἐς ὀψέ Id. 8.23; but εἰς ὀ. ψηφίζεσθαι continue voting till late in the day, D. 57.15.
ὀ. τῆς ἡμέρας late in the day, ἤδη γὰρ τῆς ἡμέρας ὀ. ἦν Th. 4.93, cf. X. HG 2.1.23; τῆς δʼ ὥρας ἐγίγνετʼ ὀ. D. 21.84; ὀ. τῆς ἡλικίας late in life, Luc. Dem.Enc. 14, cf. Am. 37.

data.quote: ἤδη γὰρ τῆς ἡμέρας ὀ. ἦν

children.definition: ὀ. τούτων after these things, Philostr. VA 6.10, cf. 4.18; so perh. ὀ. σαββάτων after the sabbath day, Ev.Matt. 28.1.—For the Comp. and Sup. Advbs.v. ὄψιος.
wish to see, c. gen., ἀϋτῆς καὶ πολέμοιο Il. 14.37: impf. ὤψεον in Sophr. 81.
Plu. QConv. 2.664a (from Pl. R. 372c, ubi codd. ἑψήματα), Str. 7.4.6, Longus 3.5.
evening, like ὀψία, Gloss.
Theodorid. ap. Ath. 6.229b.

the latter part of day, evening, opp. ὄρθρος, freq. joined with δείλη (q. v.), μέχρι δείλης ὀψίης Hdt. 7.167; περὶ δείλην ὀ. Th. 8.26; δείλης ὀ. late in the evening, D. 57.9; ὀψίας alone, POxy. 528.5 (ii A. D.).—Cf. ὄψιος.

definition: ὀψιαίτερος, ὀψιαίτατος, Att. Comp. and Sup. of ὄψιος.

children.definition: bloom late, Thphr. HP 6.2.6.
late-blooming, Thphr. HP 6.4.4, 6.6.10.

obsidian, Plinyʼs obsiana (neut. pl.), HN 36.196, cf. Peripl.M.Rubr. 5, Orph. L. 285, Cyran. 26: written ὀψειανόν PLeid.X. 36 B.; [ ὀψ]ειανόν dub. in Supp.Epigr. 2.776 i 15 ( Syria, iii A. D.). (Named from its discoverer Obsius, v. Plin. l.c.; obsidiana is f.l. ibid.; prob. ᾱ by nature.)
sprout or shoot late, Thphr. HP 6.2.6.
late sprouting or shooting, Thphr. HP 1.14.3, 6.6.10.
= foreg. [ὀψιβλαστής], Thphr. HP 3.4.2: Comp. -ότερος Id. CP 1.10.7.
marry late, Vett.Val. 119.3.
late marriage, Cat.Cod.Astr. 8(4).143, Suid. s.v. ὑπεργαμία.
for putting off marriage beyond the appointed age, Aristo Stoic. 1.89, Plu. Lys. 30.
late-married, Vett.Val. 118.23, prob. f.l. in Plu. Am. prol. 2.493e.
late-born, Hsch., Phot.; also ὀψιγέννητος, Hsch.
posteritas, Gloss.
late-born, τί σευ ἄλλος ὀνήσεται ὀψίγονός περ ; Il. 16.31, cf. Thphr. Fr. 30.6: mostly in pl., ὀψιγόνων ἀνθρώπων of men after-born, Il. 3.353, cf. Od. 1.302, etc.

data.quote: τί σευ ἄλλος ὀνήσεται ὀψίγονός περ ;

children.definition: late-born, born in oneʼs old age, h.Cer. 165, Arr. Ind. 9.2; born late in the season, ἔριφος Longus 4.6.
later-born, i.e. younger, A. Supp. 361 (lyr.), Hdt. 7.3; young, Theoc. 24.31.
late in spawning, of the needle-fish, Arist. HA 571a2.

do, go, or come late, X. An. 4.5.5, HG 6.5.21, Plu. Lyc. 12:— Pass., ὀψίζεσθαι ἐν ταῖς ὁδοῖς to be in the streets late at night, Lys. Fr. 18, cf. X. Cyn. 6.4; ὑπὸ θήρας ὀψισθέντες belated, benighted, Id. Lac. 6.4; ὠψίσθημεν τῆς ἀναγωγῆς Hld. 5.22.
to be late in fruiting, Thphr. CP 1.17.9.
late fruiting, Thphr. HP 3.2.1.
fruiting late, Thphr. HP 6.4.6, al.
one who steals at night, f.l. in Polem.Phgn. 2.5.
going late to bed, late-watching, ὄμματα A. Ag. 889.
learn late, Luc. Merc.Cond. 23.

late in learning, late to learn, Isoc. 10.2, Pl. Sph. 251b, Epicur. Fr. 173; ὀψιμαθεῖς scis quam sint insolentes, Cic. Fam. 9.20.2: c. gen., τῶν πλεονεξιῶν X. Cyr. 1.6.35; κακῶν Isoc. 12.96; τῆς ἀδικίας οἷόν ἐστιν Pl. R. 409b.

children.label: II
children.definition: vain of late-gotten learning, pedantic, Thphr. Char. 27, Timae. 70, Luc. Salt. 33.
late-gotten learning, Thphr. Char. 27, Plb. 12.4c. 1, Plu. Alex. fort. 2.334c, QConv. 634d, Iamb. VP 31.209, etc.
coming late to battle, Nonn. D. 28.92 codd.

definition: ὄψιμος, ον, ( ὀψέ) poet. for ὄψιος,

children.definition: late, slow, τέρας ὄ. for (concerned with) a late time, Il. 2.325: in Prose, late in the season, σπόρος X. Oec. 17.4, 5, but f.l. for ὄψιος in Thphr. HP 1.9.7, al.; of crops, LXX Ex. 9.32, PSI 4.433.2 (iii B. C.), PCair.Zen. 299.2 (iii B. C.); ἐν τοῖς ὀ. τῶν ὑδάτων D.S. 1.10; ὑετὸς πρώϊμος καὶ ὄ. Ep.Jac. 5.7: Comp., καιρὸς -ώτερος PFay. 133.9 (iii A. D.); recent, ποιητική Plu. QConv. 2.674f. Adv. -μως PTeb. 72.361 (ii B. C.), POxy. 474.24 (ii A. D.), Procl. ad Hes. Op. 483.
late-observing, i.e. remiss, inobservant, of Epimetheus, Pi. P. 5.28.
Phryn. 35, but found in later writers, as Peripl.M.Rubr. 32, Ptol. Alm. 8.4, PMasp. 61.2 (vi A. D.), and mentioned by A.D. Synt. 111.5, al., Dosith. p.397 K.

definition: ὀψίον, τό, Dim. of ὄψον, Them. Or. 13.173a.

children.definition: late, ὀψίᾳ ἐν νυκτί Pi. I. 4(3).35(53); ὅταν ἔαρ ὄ. γένηται Arist. HA 553b20, cf. 627b20; ὄ. σῦκα, πυροί, etc., Thphr. HP 2.8.1, 8.4.3, etc.; [ ᾠὰ] τὰ μὲν πρώϊα τὰ δʼ ὄ. Arist. HA 543a10; cf. ὀψία.

children.label: II
children.definition: Att. Comp. ὀψιαίτερος, α, ον, later, Id. Mete. 362a24, al., Thphr. CP 1.10.5: Sup. ὀψιαίτατος, η, ον, X. HG 5.4.3: hence ὀψιαίτερον as Adv., Comp. of ὀψέ, Pl. Cra. 433a, Thphr. HP 3.2.1, Eub. 119.11: Sup. ὀψιαίτατα, opp. πρωϊαίτατα, Pl. Prt. 326c, X. HG 4.5.18, etc.: also Comp. ὀψιέστερος as v.l. in Thphr. ( CP 4.8.3, HP 3.4.6): also shortd. form ὀψιτέρα, ἅλωσις Pi. Pae. 6.82; ὀψίτερον Plu. Cons.Apoll. 2.119c; ὀψίτατον Poll. 1.69; ὀψίτερον τῆς ὥρας BGU 759.6 (ii A. D.), cf. PTeb. 230 (ii B. C.).
lateness, opp. πρωϊότης, Thphr. CP 4.11.9.
one who has long been in fetters, Men. 1049 (pl.).

definition: ὄψις, ἡ, gen. εως, Ion. ιος, ( ὄπωπα):

children.label: I
children.definition: aspect, appearance of a person or thing, πατρὸς φίλου ὄψιν ἀτυχθείς Il. 6.468; εἰσορόων ὄ. τʼ ἀγαθὴν καὶ μῦθον ἀκούων 24.632, cf. S. Ph. 1412 (anap.); δῶρον, οὐ σπουδαῖον εἰς ὄ. Id. OC 577; πλείω τὴν ὄ. παρείχετο made the appearance greater, Th. 6.46; ἀξιόλογον ὄ. παρέχεται τὸ δένδρος PCair.Zen. 157.4 (iii B. C.); ὥστε ὄ. καλὴν φαίνεσθαι X. An. 5.9.9; εἰκάζεσθαι ἀπὸ τῆς φανερᾶς ὄ. Th. 1.10; τὴν ὄ. τοῦ σώματος προορᾶν Id. 7.44: the acc. is used abs., in appearance, τῷ ὄψιν ἐειδόμενος Pi. N. 10.15; στρογγύλος τὴν ὄ. Hermipp. 4; ἀστειότατον τὴν ὄ. Alex. 59; καλός τε κἀγαθὸς τὴν ὄ. Pl. Prm. 127b; ἀπὸ τῆς ὄ. Ἑλληνικός to judge from his looks, Antiph. 33.2; so ἐκ τῆς ὄ. POxy. 37 ii 3 (i A. D.).

data.quote: εἰσορόων ὄ. τʼ ἀγαθὴν καὶ μῦθον ἀκούων

children.label: b
children.definition: countenance, face, E. Med. 905, Pl. Phdr. 240d, 254b, etc.; διοίδησις ὅλης ὄ. Herod.Med. in Rh.Mus. 58.83, cf. Sor. 1.44, Philum. ap. Aët. 9.7; οὐκ ἄξιον ἀπʼ ὄψεως οὔτε φιλεῖν οὔτε μισεῖν οὐδένα by the face or look merely, Lys. 16.19; ἀδήλως τῇ ὄ. πλασάμενος so that nothing could be learnt from his countenance, Th. 6.58; τίνι δεδούλωταί ποτε; ὄψει Men. 541.2: pl., Alex. 98.6, Anaxandr. 41.38.

children.label: c
children.definition: visual impression or image of an object, Pl. Tht. 193c.

thing seen, sight, φοβερὰν ὄ. προσιδέσθαι A. Pers. 48 (anap.), cf. Supp. 567 (lyr.); ὁρῶ Πυλάδην . . , ἡδεῖαν ὄ. E. Or. 727, cf. Pl. Lg. 887d, etc.; ἄλλην ὄ. οἰκοδομημάτων other architectural sights, Hdt. 2.136; τὰ δὲ χρήματα . . ἔστιν ὄψις mere outside show, Antiph. 33.2; πολλὴν ὄ. παρασχόντα ἔπειτα μηδὲν ὠφελῆσαι Hp. Art. 44; of scenic representations, Arist. Po. 1453b1, al.; ὁ τῆς ὄ. κόσμος ib. 1449b33: pl., ib. 1462a16.

data.quote: πολλὴν ὄ. παρασχόντα ἔπειτα μηδὲν ὠφελῆσαι

children.definition: vision, apparition, Hdt. 1.39, etc.; ὄ. ἐν τῷ ὕπνῳ Id. 3.30, al.; ὄ. ἐνυπνίου Id. 8.54; ὄ. ὀνείρου Id. 1.38; ὄ. ἔννυχοι A. Pr. 645, cf. Ag. 425 (lyr.), S. El. 413, E. Hec. 72 (lyr.), IG 42(1).121.11 ( Epid., iv B. C.), etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: power of sight or seeing, vision, ὄψει τινὰ ἰδεῖν, ἐσιδεῖν, Il. 20.205, Od. 25.94, cf. Heraclit. 55, Democr. 11, Emp. 4.10, Th. 7.75, etc.; τῆς ἐμῆς ὄ. Hdt. 2.99, 147; τῆς ὄ. στερηθῆναι Id. 9.93, etc.; οὐ τὸ δρασθὲν πιστότερον ὄψει λαβόντες ἢ τὸ ἀκουσθέν Th. 3.38; οὐ καθορωμένους τῇ ὄ. νυκτὸς οὔσης ib. 112.

children.label: b
children.definition: act of seeing or looking, ἡ εἰς τὸ ἄνω ὄ. Pl. Cra. 396b; sense of sight, Arist. de An. 428a6, Mete. 369b9; τὰ διὰ τῆς ὄ., of pleasures, Id. EN 1118a3, etc.

children.label: c
children.definition: organs of sight, eyes, ὄψεις μαρᾶναι to quench the orbs of sight, S. OT 1328, cf. Ant. 52, Heraclit. 26; τὸ κάλλος πάντων εἷλκε τὰς ὄ. ἐπʼ αὐτόν X. Smp. 1.9; ἀσθενῖ ( = -εῖ) τὰς ὄ. POxy. 911.6 (iii A. D.): so in sg., ἐστερήθη τῆς μιᾶς ὄ. Plb. 3.79.12: sg. in collective sense, the eyes, [ ἰχθῦς] λευκὴν ἔχοντες τὴν ὄ. Arist. HA 602a11, cf. PA 656b29.

data.quote: τὸ κάλλος πάντων εἷλκε τὰς ὄ. ἐπʼ αὐτόν

children.label: d
children.definition: iris of the eye, Hp. Prorrh. 2.19 (but eye-ball or eye, Id. Prog. 7 (pl.)); also, pupil, Ruf. Onom. 23.

children.label: e
children.definition: visual rays which were supposed to proceed from the eyes, Pl. Ti. 45c, 46b, Arist. Mete. 343a13, 370a19: in other places Arist. controverted this Empedoclean theory, Sens. 437b14.

view, sight, ἀπικνέεσθαι ἐς ὄψιν τινί come into oneʼs sight, i.e. presence, Hdt. 1.136; εἰς ὄψιν τινὸς or τινὶ ἥκειν, μολεῖν, ἐλθεῖν, περᾶν, A. Ch. 215, Pers. 183, E. Med. 173 (anap.), Or. 513; καλέσαι τινὰ ἐς ὄ. Hdt. 5.106; ἀποφαίνειν τί τινι ἐς ὄ. Id. 4.81; λυπηρὰς τῇ ὄ. ἀχθηδόνας προστιθέμενοι Th. 2.37; ἐν ὄ. τοῦ δήμου Plu. TG 12; κατʼ ὄψιν in person, ὡς ἐνετειλάμην σοι κατʼ ὄ. as I enjoined you when with you, POxy. 1154.4 (i A. D.), cf. 117.3 (ii/iii A. D.), etc.

children.label: b
children.definition: dignity, position, κατὰ τὴν ἐμὴν ὄ. καὶ ὑπόλημψιν PLond. 1.77.59 (vi A. D.); ἡ τῶν γονέων ἡμῶν προτεραία ὄ. PMasp. 2 iii6 (vi A. D.).

data.quote: κατὰ τὴν ἐμὴν ὄ. καὶ ὑπόλημψιν

children.definition: a being too late, D.H. 4.46.
sow late, Thphr. HP 8.1.7.
late-sown, to be sown late, Thphr. CP 2.12.4.
late descendant, Lyc. 1272.
late of fulfilment, τέρας ὄψιμον ὀ. Il. 2.325, cf. Tryph. 48, Nonn. D. 25.362, al.

definition: ὀψιτέλευτος, f.l. for foreg. [ὀψιτέλεστος], Nonn. D. 5.206, Sch. Il. 21.232.

children.definition: cut, or to be cut or pruned, late, Thphr. CP 3.2.3.
successful after long delay, Hdn.Gr. 2.932, Anub. in Cat.Cod.Astr. 2.209.28, Paul.Al. M. 3, Man. 5.71; ὀ. εἶ· μὴ ἀγωνία Astramps. Orac. 15.8.
late-bearing, Thphr. CP 1.17.9.
fleeing late, Hdn.Gr. 1.234.
skilful in dressing food, a clever cook, epith. of Archestratus in Ath. 3.101b; cf. λογοδαίδαλος.
want of food or fish, Suid.
= sq., Phot. s.v. κέραμον.
place for keeping victuals in, Suid. s.v. γύλιος.
cookery, Ath. 7.284e.
sample of imported foodstuff, prob. in PLond. 3.856.22 (i A. D.).
one who discourses on cookery, Ath. 8.337b.
mad after dainties, Chrysipp.Stoic. 3.167.
madness after dainties, Eust.ad D.P. 374.

cooked or otherwise prepared food, a made dish, eaten with bread and wine, ἐν δὲ . . σῖτον καὶ οἶνον ἔθηκεν, ὄψα τε Od. 3.480; ἐν δέ οἱ ἀσκὸν ἔθηκε . . οἴνοιο . . , ἐν δὲ καὶ ᾖα κωρύκῳ, ἐν δέ οἱ ὄψα τίθει 5.267, cf. 6.77, Il. 9.489; παμπόνηρον ὄ. ὁ γέρανος Epich. 87; ἄρτον, . . οἶνον . . , ὄψον Th. 1.138 (taken in signf. 3 by D.S. 11.57); ἄρτους, . . ὄψον . . , οἶνον Pl. Grg. 518c; ὄ. ὀπτόν Ar. Eq. 1106, cf. Av. 900; ἐσθίουσι ἐπὶ τῷ σίτῳ ὄ. X. Mem. 3.14.2, cf. 3.14.3; τῷ ὄ. ( cuisine) τε καὶ τῷ οἴνῳ χαίροντα μᾶλλον ἢ τοῖς φίλοις ib. 1.5.4; ὄ. ἕξουσιν, ἅλας τε δηλονότι καὶ ἐλάας καὶ τυρόν, καὶ βολβοὺς καὶ λάχανά γε, οἷα δὴ ἐν ἀγροῖς ἑψήματα, ἑψήσονται Pl. R. 372c; opp. τραγήματα, Clearch. 65; ὄψα . . καὶ τραγήματα, ὄψα . . καὶ μύρα, Pl. R. 372e, 373a; Σικελικὴ ποικιλία ὄψου ib. 404d; φακῆν, ἥδιστον ὄψων Ar. Fr. 23; τὴν ἔγχελυν . . ὄψων μέγιστον the greatest of delicacies, Anaxandr. 39.6; ὄ. δὲ ταὐτὸν ἀεί ποτε πᾶσίν ἐστιν, ὕειον κρέας ἑφθόν (in the Spartan φειδίτια) Dicaearch.Hist. 23 [72]; εἷς ἄρτος, ὄ. ἰσχάς Philem. 85, cf. X. Cyr. 1.2.8; [ τέχνη] ἡ τοῖς ὄ. ( dishes) τὰ ἡδύσματα (sauces, seasonings) [ἀποδιδοῦσα μαγειρικὴ καλεῖται] Pl. R. 332d, cf. Tht. 175e, Plu. Fort. 2.99d; ὄ. ὀξέα καὶ δριμέα καὶ ἁλμυρά X. Cyr. 6.2.31; τοὺς παῖδας διδάσκομεν . . τῇ δεξιᾷ λαμβάνειν τοῦ ὄ. τῇ δʼ ἀριστερᾷ κρατεῖν τὸν ἄρτον Plu. Fort. 2.99d: metaph., ὄ. δὲ λόγοι φθονεροῖσι are a treat to the envious, Pi. N. 8.21.

data.quote: ἐν δὲ . . σῖτον καὶ οἶνον ἔθηκεν, ὄψα τε

τοὺς παῖδας διδάσκομεν . . τῇ δεξιᾷ λαμβάνειν τοῦ ὄ. τῇ δʼ ἀριστερᾷ κρατεῖν τὸν ἄρτον

children.definition: relish, κρόμυον, ποτῷ ὄ. Il. 11.630; κολλύραν . . καὶ κόνδυλον ὄ. ἐπʼ αὐτῇ pudding and knuckle- sauce, Ar. Pax 123: metaph., λιμῷ ὅσαπερ ὄψῳ διαχρῆσθε ‘hunger is the best sauce’, X. Cyr. 1.5.12; ἡ ἐπιθυμία τοῦ σίτου ὄ. Id. Mem. 1.3.5; ὄ. τροφῆς τὸ πεινῆν Socr. ap. Porph. Abst. 3.26; οἱ πόνοι ὄ. τοῖς ἀγαθοῖς X. Cyr. 7.5.80.

fish, the chief delicacy of the Athenians ( πολλῶν ὄντων ὄ. ἐκνενίκηκεν ὁ ἰχθὺς μόνος ἢ μάλιστά γε ὄψον καλεῖσθαι Plu. QConv. 2.667f, cf. Ath. 7.276e); so in Pap., ὄ. as collective, = fish, PCair. Zen. 82.17 (iii B. C.); in Hp. Mul. 1.37 ὄψα θαλάσσια is v.l. (dub.).

data.quote: πολλῶν ὄντων ὄ. ἐκνενίκηκεν ὁ ἰχθὺς μόνος ἢ μάλιστά γε ὄψον καλεῖσθαι

children.label: II
children.definition: market-place, esp. fishmarket, εἰς τοὖψον Ar. Frr. 247, 545, cf. Aeschin. 1.65.
to be an ὀψονόμος, Critias 60 D.
one who watches the price of fish, Sophil. 2.
Hsch.
oven for baking food, Hsch. s.v. πύρδαλον.
dress food (esp. fish) nicely, Alex. 24.1, Plu. QConv. 2.663c, etc.: metaph., ὀ. λόγον make a dainty speech, ib. Adul. 55a:— Med., c. acc. cogn., X. Mem. 3.14.5: abs., Id. HG 7.2.22, D. 54.4.
a dainty dish: generally, food, LXX Ju. 12.1, Gp. 20.18 tit.
of or fit for delicate cookery: ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη) the art of cookery, Arist. EN 1153a26, Metaph. 1027a4; for cooking purposes, μάκτρα PRyl. 127.34 (i A. D.).
cookery, esp. fine cookery, X. Mem. 3.14.5, Pl. Grg. 462d; ὁ τὴν ὀ. συγγεγραφὼς τὴν Σικελικήν who wrote the Sicilian cookery-book, ib. 518b.
Pl. Grg. 465d, X. Oec. 9.7: ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη), = ὀψοποιητική, Pl. Grg. 463b, 465d (here with v.l. -ητική), Arist. Pol. 1255b26 (as v.l. for -ητική); coupled with κομμωτική, Phld. Rh. 2.183 S.

children.definition: one who cooks food, a cook, distd. from ἀρτοκόπος or ἀρτοποιός, Hdt. 9.82, X. HG 7.1.38, Cyr. 5.5.39; from σιτοποιός, ib. 8.5.3, Pl. Grg. 517e; from μάγειρος, Id. R. 373c, cf. Tht. 178d; οὐκέτι μάγειρος ὀ. δʼ ἐστί που Dionys.Com. 2.9; τὸν ὀ. σκευάσαι χρηστῶς μόνον δεῖ τοὖψον Alex. 149.6: metaph., τοὺς εἰωθότας τῶν λόγων ὀ. Chor. Brum. 14.18.

data.quote: οὐκέτι μάγειρος ὀ. δʼ ἐστί που
τὸν ὀ. σκευάσαι χρηστῶς μόνον δεῖ τοὖψον

children.definition: dressing food elaborately, AP 6.306.
victualler, esp. fishmonger, Gloss.:—fem. ὀψό-πωλις (sc. ἀγορά), ιδος, fishmarket, Clearch. 16, Plu. Tim. 14; cf. sq. [ὀψοπωλία]
fishmarket, Str. 14.2.21.
fishshop, Str. 17.2.4 (pl.), Lyd. Mens. 4.138, Suid.
LXX Nu. 11.22.
Cerc. 6.13.
eat delicacies, live daintily, Ar. Nu. 983; ἡ μέλισσα πρὸς σάρκα . . οὐθενὸς καθίζει, οὐδʼ ὀψοφαγεῖ does not settle on cooked dishes, Arist. HA 625b21.
dainty living, Aeschin. 1.42 (pl.), Theopomp. Hist. 179, Arist. EE 1231a20, Philostr. VA 1.9.

children.label: II
children.definition: fish-diet, Zeno Stoic. 1.66.

one who eats delicacies, such as fish and other dainties, epicure, gourmet, Ar. Pax 810, Cephisod. 9, Antiph. 190.5, Eub. 88, Arist. EN 1118a32; ὀ. εἶ καὶ κνισολοιχός Sophil. 7, cf. X. Mem. 3.14.2 sq., Timae. 71: epith. of a fish, Opp. H. 1.141: irreg. Att. Sup. ὀψοφαγίστατος X. Mem. 3.13.4, Poll. 6.37.
carrying food, Matro Conv. 47, Poll. 10.91.

definition: ὀψῶνα τὴν πρὸς τὸ ὀψωνεῖν σπυρίδα, Hsch.

children.definition: caterer, Ath. 4.171a (from Lat. obsonator, cf. AB 339.14).

buy fish and other dainties, ὀψωνεῖν ἔοιχʼ ἅνθρωπος ἐπὶ τυραννίδι Ar. V. 495: c. acc., τριχίδας ὀ. Eup. 154; καρκίνους Ar. V. 1506; ὑπογάστρια Antiph. 192.1, etc.: generally, buy victuals, cater, X. Mem. 3.14.1: prov., Δελφοῖσι θύσας αὐτὸς ὀψωνεῖ κρέας ap. Plu. QConv. 2.709a.
one who buys fish or victuals, caterer, purveyor, Ar. Fr. 503, Alciphr. 1.1:—also ὀψων-ητής, Arr. Epict. 3.26.21, Tz. H. 5.534.
of or for purveying, τέχνη Ath. 6.228c, 7.313f.

purchase of fish, etc., catering, Critias 60 D., Antiph. 184, Alex. 186.2; ἔφερε ἕκαστος . . πρὸς τούτοις (viz. food) εἰς ὀ. μικρόν τι κομιδῇ νομίσματος (in the Spartan φειδίτια) Plu. Lyc. 12, cf. Dicaearch.Hist. 23.

furnish with provisions, ὀ. τὰς δυνάμεις furnish an army with supplies or pay, Plb. 15.25.11, cf. D.S. 33.22:— Pass., to be supplied, PCair.Zen. 499.42 (iii B. C.), Plb. 23.8.4, dub. l. in Str. 14.2.5; ἐκ τῶν ἀλλοτρίων χρημάτων D.H. 4.19, cf. D.S. 16.22.
furnishing with provisions, Men. 1050.
supplies and pay of an army, Plb. 1.66.7, 1.69.7, D.H. 8.68.
caterer, PLips. 97 xii 8, al. (iv A. D.).
Cat.Cod.Astr. 8(4).137.
receiving provisions, σπυρίς Poll. 10.92.

salary, reckoned in money, τό τε ὀ. καὶ σιτομετρίαν καὶ τὸ ἔλαιον PCair.Zen. 507.5, cf. 421.6, 483.14, 498.5 (all iii B. C.); ἵνα ἡμῖν ὀ. προστεθῇ καὶ σιτάριον ib. 49.4 (iii B. C.); μετρήματα καὶ ὀ. corn- and money-payments, UPZ 14.26 (ii B. C.); φυλακιτῶν PPetr. 3p.230 (iii B. C.); of a bank clerk, PCair.Zen. 342.6 (iii B. C.): distd. from γραμματικόν (bonus on turnover), PStrassb. 105.4 (iii B. C.); χωρὶς ὀψωνίων, of un salaried services, Inscr.Prien. 121.34 (i B. C.).

C.), Plb. 6.39.12: so in pl., pay of an army, Rev.Ét.Anc. 33.8 ( Theangela, iv/iii B. C.), OGI 229.106 (iii B. C.), SIG 410.19 (iii B. C.), 581.34 (ii/i B. C.), Plb. 1.67.1, 3.25.4, LXX 1 Ma. 3.28, Aristeas 22.

allowance paid to a victorious athlete, PRyl. 153.25 (ii A. D.), CPHerm. 54.7, al. (iii A. D.); allowance or scholarship paid to a music-student, προδοῦναί μοι τὸ ὀ. καὶ τὸ κατὰ μῆνα ἀνάλωμα PCair.Zen. 440.6 (iii B. C.); allowance to a son or daughter, BGU 665 ii 15 (i A. D.), POxy. 898.31 (ii A. D.); to a slave, distd. from ἱματις μός, PCair.Zen. 28.6, 100.14 (iii B. C.).

data.quote: προδοῦναί μοι τὸ ὀ. καὶ τὸ κατὰ μῆνα ἀνάλωμα

children.definition: wages of labour, τὰ σώματα ἐνοχλεῖ ἡμᾶς τὰ ὀ. ἀπαιτοῦντα ib. 43.2, cf. 27.2, al., PPetr. 2p.113 (all iii B. C.), POxy. 974 (iii A. D.); ἀρτάβην κριθῆς εἰς λόγον ὀψωνίων PTeb. 420.24 (iii A. D.): metaph., ὀψώνια ἁμαρτίας the wages of sin, Ep.Rom. 6.23.
fee, PMag.Par. 1.2454.
gratuity to tax-farmers, UPZ 112v3 (pl.).

obsonium), τῶν ἀνηλωμάτων πάντων σίτου καὶ ὀψωνίων ib. 91.13 (ii B. C.).—The word is rejected by Phryn. 393. First used by Men. 1051 (no context); ᾔτησεν εἰς ὀ. τριώβολον Thugen. 2. Glossed ὀψωνία, also (in pl.) κέρδη, χαρίσματα, by Phot.
victualler, Gloss.
